docs.abstract: Activists Hu Jia and his wife Zeng Jinyan are barred from leaving China and placed under house arrest; Hu says that officials are worried that they would set off opposition to Beijing's hosting of 2008 Summer Olympics (M)

headline.main: 2 Activists Are Under House Arrest and Barred From Leaving China

docs.snippet: China barred an AIDS and human rights activist and his wife from leaving the country and placed them under house arrest.
docs.lead_paragraph: A young Chinese couple who have promoted a variety of delicate social and political causes were barred from leaving the country on Friday and placed under house arrest, the couple said. The police barred Hu Jia, 33, and his wife, Zeng Jinyan, 23, from departing from Beijing on a trip to Hong Kong and several European countries, Mr. Hu said. The couple had planned to call attention to what they described as a neglect of AIDS patients and to defend other Chinese campaigners for human rights who had been prosecuted in recent months.

docs.snippet: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a woman who says she may be jailed during the Beijing Games. The encampment for petitioners like her was already demolished in preparation for the Olympics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a woman who says she may be jailed during the Beijing Games. The encampment for petitioners like her was already demolished in preparation for the Olympics.

docs.abstract: Photos of athletes training for 2008 Paralympics in Beijing
docs.snippet: In early May, retired and active duty troops attended the 2007 Paralympic military sports camp at the Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs.     For some, it was a step toward rehabilitation.
docs.lead_paragraph: In early May, retired and active duty troops attended the 2007 Paralympic military sports camp at the Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs. For some, it was a step toward rehabilitation.

docs.abstract: Swift rise of Chongqing, with population of 12 million, represents new push by government to spread fruits of China's economic boom to interior, home to 75 percent of population; government is encouraging tens of millions to move to cities from rural areas; estimates are 50 percent of population will live in cities and towns by 2011, compared with 18 percent in 1978; Chongqing, drawing 200,000 new residents annually, could rival Shanghai and Beijing as nation's biggest city in decade; photos; map (M)

headline.main: Big, Gritty Chongqing, City of 12 Million, Is China's Model for Future

docs.snippet: China’s rush to build megacities is part of a major push to spread China’s economic boom to the vast interior.

multimedia.caption: Chongqing, a Chinese Megacity
multimedia.credit: China’s rush to build megacities is part of a major push to spread China’s economic boom to the vast interior.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: China’s rush to build megacities is part of a major push to spread China’s economic boom to the vast interior.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stand in the right spot in this gigantic city and hills draped with apartment complexes can remind you of Hong Kong, the density of habitation will recall Tokyo and the river-spanning brawn, replete with an immense new structure over the Yangtze that echoes the Brooklyn Bridge, might recall New York. Everywhere one looks here, there are new expressways, new bridges and towering new housing complexes rising, so many in fact that it is the occasional glimpse of something old, rather than the sight of anything new, that takes one's breath away.

docs.abstract: Hurdler Liu Xiang prepares to compete at Reebok Grand Prix; photo (M)

headline.main: A Runner Who Is Taking Each Hurdle as It Comes

docs.snippet: Hurdler Liu Xiang says he takes each day as it comes, a philosophy that has put him at odds with millions of his Chinese compatriots, who have been projecting Liu’s star turn at next year’s Beijing Olympics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Liu Xiang approaches life the same way he does the hurdles. He says he takes each day as it comes, instead of letting his focus drift to what lies ahead. His philosophy has put him at odds with millions of his Chinese compatriots, who have been projecting Liu's star turn at next year's Beijing Olympics since his gold-medal performance in the 110-meter hurdles at the 2004 Games in Athens.

docs.abstract: Photo of Hong Kong crowd observing 18th anniversary of China's crackdown on Tiananmen Square demonstrations in Beijing
docs.snippet: Photo of Hong Kong crowd observing 18th anniversary of China's crackdown on Tiananmen Square demonstrations in Beijing

docs.abstract: Candlelight vigil is held in Hong Kong to observe 18th anniversary of military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing; event draws unusually large crowd, in apparent response to recent assertion by Ma Lik, leader of Hong Kong's pro-China party, that no massacre took place; Tiananmen Square itself remains quiet, if under tight security; several well-known dissidents are placed under house arrest or close watch, though some describe harassment as more passive than in years past (M)

headline.main: Hong Kong's Tiananmen Vigil Draws Crowd After Official's Denial

docs.snippet: By contrast, Tiananmen Square itself remained quiet, if under tight security, on a sunny day, with the usual tour groups and pedestrians milling about.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER; Jim Yardley contributed reporting from Beijing

docs.lead_paragraph: A candlelight vigil here on Monday evening to observe the 18th anniversary of the military crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in Beijing drew an unusually large crowd, apparently in response to the recent assertion by the leader of Hong Kong's pro-China party that no massacre took place. By contrast, Tiananmen Square itself remained quiet, if under tight security, on a sunny day, with the usual tour groups and pedestrians milling about. Several well-known dissidents had been placed under house arrest or close watch, though some described the harassment as more passive than in years past.

docs.abstract: China releases its first national strategy on climate change, issue high on agenda for world's industrial powers gathering for Group of 8 meeting in Germany; China's plan promises to improve energy efficiency but rejects any mandatory caps on greenhouse gas emissions; plan seen partly as rebuff to separate efforts by Pres Bush and European nations to draw China into commitment to reduce emissions; China, with world's fastest-growing major economy, is expected to surpass US in next few years as world's biggest emitter of greenhouse gases; China has resisted mandatory reductions in emissions, arguing that it is still a developing country and needs to balance environmental improvements with maintaining economic growth; photo (M)

headline.main: China Issues Plan on Global Warming, Rejecting Mandatory Caps on Greenhouse Gases

docs.snippet: The plan served at least partly as a rebuff to separate efforts by President Bush and European nations to draw China and other developing countries into a commitment to reduce emissions.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY and ANDREW C. REVKIN; Jim Yardley reported from Beijing, and Andrew C. Revkin from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: With global warming high on the agenda for the world's industrial powers gathering later this week in Germany, China staked out its position on Monday by releasing its first national strategy on climate change, a plan that promises to improve energy efficiency but rejects any mandatory caps on greenhouse gas emissions. The 62-page plan, two years in the making, served at least partly as a rebuff to separate efforts by President Bush and European nations to draw China and other developing countries into a commitment to reduce emissions, which was expected to be a focal point at the expanded summit meeting of the Group of 8 industrialized nations.

docs.abstract: Wu Bangguo, chairman of China's Standing Committee of National People's Congress, says at conference in Beijing that Hong Kong has considerable autonomy only because central government in Beijing chose to authorize that autonomy (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China Reminds Hong Kong Who's Boss

docs.snippet: Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-B
docs.lead_paragraph: Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, China promised Britain that as part of the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule China would preserve ''a high degree of autonomy'' for the territory. But Chinese officials focus these days on the Basic Law, a Beijing-drafted document that serves as Hong Kong's mini-constitution and gives broad powers to the Standing Committee in Beijing to set policy in Hong Kong by interpreting the territory's laws. Mr. Wu spoke ahead of the 10th anniversary on July 1 of Hong Kong's return to China. KEITH BRADSHER

docs.abstract: China's government, in effort to conserve energy, urges office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear; air-conditioning in many government offices has been turned off and inspectors sent to hotels and office buildings in Beijing to enforce new temperature guidelines (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Workers Told To Wear T-Shirts To Save Energy

docs.snippet: In an effort to conserve energy, the government has urged office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear. The message was delivered in a week when air-conditioning in many government offices was turned off and i
docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to conserve energy, the government has urged office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear. The message was delivered in a week when air-conditioning in many government offices was turned off and inspectors sent to hotels and office buildings in Beijing to enforce new temperature guidelines. HOWARD W. FRENCH
